awd_titl_txt: Nonlinear Vibrations of Systems of MEMS Oscillators
awd_abstract_narration:
Micro-scale and nano-scale electromechanical systems are extremely small (microscopic) devices which are used in sensing, navigation, clocks, printers, drug delivery, personal health care and other applications.  For example, mobile phones contain multiple micro-scale sensors which function to determine which direction is up, to measure pressure and temperature, or to find magnetic North of the Earth.  Many micro systems incorporate vibrating, or resonant, micron to nanometer scale flexible structures. The structural elements could be as simple as a cantilever beam etched from a silicon wafer, to complex three-dimensional architectures built from multiple layers of materials.  As a result the "design space" for resonant micro-scale oscillators is tremendous.  Making best use of this space requires a deep understanding of materials, fabrication, packaging, electronics, optics and mechanics.  This project will focus on advancing knowledge of the nonlinear dynamics of single, pairs and arrays of resonators and oscillators.  Discoveries enabled by the project will enlarge the design space and potentially lead to new technologies and devices. A new generation of scientists will be trained in this research. In addition to their training in traditional scientific disciplines, as a result of the international collaboration, they will develop an understanding and appreciation of the synergies of collaborative research that bridges geographical distances. The project will also result in undergraduates inspired through meaningful participation in research to excel in their studies and to pursue graduate degrees in STEM. The researchers will be encouraged to consider transfer technology developed from this research into existing or startup companies to promote economic development.

The research will involve physical experiments on optically self-excited micron- down to nanometer-size scale devices, closely coupled to mathematical modeling and analysis.  The experiments and models will start with an optically excited single oscillator, then build to pairs and arrays coupled through electrostatic or magnetic fields. Specific goals include:  demonstrating locking of oscillator pairs and arrays, observing new phenomena, improving frequency stability, quantifying the relation of system response to key parameters and developing, analyzing and validating mathematical models that enhance understanding of observed phenomena and that underlie the design of MEMS systems. Through the experimental work and associated mathematical models the project will advance knowledge in the field of dynamics of nonlinear oscillators by addressing questions on the feasibility of and conditions for entrainment and locking of arrays of limit cycle oscillators physically realized as micron scale devices.  Spanning the needed expertise in experimental mechanics, theory, design and fabrication, the project brings together an experienced research team from Cornell University, Tel Aviv University and the National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST).
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: SENSORS AND SENSOR SYSTEMS FOR CIS

por.por_cntn:
This project involved experimental, theoretical and computational research into the vibrations of sub-millimeter scale mechanical devices known as MEMS, short for Microelectromechanical Systems.  The MEMS in this study are fabricated from a silicon wafer of a type used in the manufacture of electronic chips.  In this work the devices are doubly clamped, beams, similar to highway overpass bridges. But these bridges won?t take you far, they are only 0.04 mm long and 0.0002 mm thick. The beams are connected, or coupled, to each other with cross bridges that act as springs.

 

Being extremely small, these MEMS beams and require special equipment to view them and to determine their dynamical behavior.  We use a laser to illuminate the specimen and then pass the reflected light into a signal analyzer in order to determine the dynamical state of the MEMS beams.  In the process of so doing it turns out that the laser light heats the MEMS beam, producing motion and thermal stresses which enter into the dynamics of the system.

 

With sufficient laser light these beams will vibrate on their own, undergoing what are called limit cycle oscillations.  What is new in our work, and has been achieved for the first time, is to illuminate two adjacent, coupled, detuned (i.e. different resonant frequency) beams at once, setting them both into limit cycle motion and allowing us to study the conditions under which the two beams will vibrate in synchrony or will each vibrate at their own frequency.  

 

Our theoretical results show that simple mathematical models of the experiments predict that as the stiffness of the spring that couples, or connects, the two beams varies a complex sequence of different types of behaviors can occur, including modes of vibration in which the beams move at the same frequency in the same direction (in-phase), move in opposite directions (out-of-phase)  or drift, i.e. move at separate frequencies.  A more realistic and complex model of the experiments was explored using high performance computing.  An unexpected result is that keeping the coupling spring stiffness and the amount of detuning constant, the system can respond as either in-phase, synchronized motions or drifting motion.  The determining factor is the starting position of each beam.  Extremely small changes in the starting point can kick the system into one response or the other.  The experimental manifestation of this result is that in some cases, even for a stiff coupling spring, a pair of beams will spontaneously switch between moving in synch and out of synch. 

 

Results from the project were disseminated through a series of nine articles and were discussed at seven technical conferences.  In addition, the project provided training opportunities for three Ph.D. students (one graduated, two current) who gained experience and skills not only in their technical areas but in project management, writing and oral communications, teamwork and outreach.  In collaboration with the NSF funded Cornell Center for Materials research, the project faculty and students participated in a number of science outreach activities reaching students and teachers both near Cornell University and further afield in New York and Washington DC. 

 


Last Modified: 01/01/2022
Modified by: Alan T Zehnder
